Korean Accord Stirs Missile Defense Debate The summit meeting between the Korean leaders has left the Clinton administration divided over North Korea's intentions, but has not diminished its resolve to go ahead with a missile defense, officials say.
INTERNATIONAL

Korean Accord Stirs Missile Defense Debate The summit meeting between the Korean leaders has left the Clinton administration divided over North Korea's intentions, but has not diminished its resolve to go ahead with a missile defense, officials say.
Hundreds of protestors demanding the withdrawal of American troops clashed with riot police in South Korea, leaving at least 20 people injured.

Reservists Adapt to New Role Guard and Reserve commanders argue that the nation's citizen-soldiers, with their experience and skills honed in the civilian world, may in fact be better prepared than their active-duty counterparts for the subtle tasks of rebuilding a nation devastated by war, like Bosnia.

Syria Unites Behind New Leader Syria's Baath Party, the structural support beneath the 30-year rule of the late Hafez al-Assad, gathered to pledge allegiance to his son, Bashar, and to vest him formally with the political authority he has quietly exercised for the last two years.
Zimbabwe Election Approaches President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, with parliamentary elections a week away, blamed campaign violence on the opposition and urged thousands to keep the peace.

Air Control Fails in Britain The failure of an air traffic controller computer delayed flights in and out of British airports as well as flights crossing over the country. The National Air Traffic Services promised a thorough investigation.
NATIONAL

Parties' Differences On Drug Plans Widen Medicare drug benefits have emerged as one of the more potent political issues in this year's elections. Both Republicans and Democrats say the goal is to make drug coverage available and affordable, but the parties' differences on the details are widening by the day.
Border Ranches Besieged Ranches around Douglas, Ariz., have come under siege by migrants seeking illegal entry into the United States as other crossing points have become harder to penetrate.

Reversal in Crime Feared Law enforcement officials and criminologists believe that the decline in violent crime may have finally come to an end, with the number of homicides in some big cities rising in recent months.

California Official in Scandal California's insurance commissioner is fighting charges that he allowed insurance companies to shortchange earthquake victims in return for contributions to a political slush fund.

A Virginia Senate Race Tightens Senator Charles S. Robb of Virginia has rallied in a race to defend his seat. Once trailing, he is now about even with the Republican challenger, former Gov. George F. Allen.

Bush Criticizes Security Lapses Gov. George W. Bush crisscrossed Florida and criticized security lapses at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, saying ''America's nuclear security should not be a matter of lost and found.''
NEW YORK/REGION

Defective Aircraft Cable Draws Different Responses After a company from upstate New York acknowledged that it had sold faulty cable for years to both military and civilian aircraft manufacturers, the response from the military was starkly different from that of the F.A.A.

Way Off Broadway On any given night there are 20 to 30 small, low-budget plays or musicals performed in the city that are unknown to even the most stalwart of theatergoers. They are supported in a city that is full of talented people, forgotten material, willing audiences and not enough work for actors.

Plan for Spraying Canceled New York City health officials called off plans to spray insecticide in Queens after two laboratories concluded that a chicken thought to have contracted the West Nile virus was not infected.
